page.title: 03Barby\Willoughby\Farming
page.content:
The entry for Barby in the original Domesday book indicates that the land was used primarily for agriculture. Nothing has changed. The soil is best for grass production and consequently two thirds is used for pasture. The remaining third is used for growing barley, wheat, oats and oil seed rape. Grass is also grown as a crop. Because of recent changes in EEC milk production quotas, many farmers have changed from milk to beef production.
A ruined windmill stands at the Southern end of Barby and the site has undergone an interesting change of use, for it is being converted into a trout farm - no doubt taking advantage of several natural springs. Beyond the trout farm on the Daventry Road a thriving Nursery Garden has been established to supply a Rugby Nursery.
